titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Reginald Gammon Papers, 1927-2007, bulk 1960-2005, in the Archives of American Art AAA.gammreg
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Dominique Luster

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 272096

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-11-05T08:01-0500

did.abstract: The Reginald Gammon papers measure 2.4 linear feet and date from 1927 to 2007 (bulk 1960-2005). The papers contain biographical material, personal and professional correspondence, writings and artwork by Gammon, printed material, and photographs regarding Gammon's career as a painter, educator, and prominent member of the African American art scene.
did.langmaterial: The collection is in English. Some correspondence is in French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Reginald Gammon papers measure 2.4 linear feet and date from 1927 to 2007 (bulk 1960-2005). The papers contain biographical material, personal and professional correspondence, writings and artwork by Gammon, printed material, and photographs regarding Gammon's career as a painter, educator, and prominent member of the African American art scene.

A small selection of biographic information about Gammon includes certificates, military documentation, and interviews. Approximately half of the collection consists of correspondence with other artists, museums, galleries and arts organizations. Correspondence documents his work with a number of African American arts organizations across the country. Of note is correspondence with Benny Andrews, Romare Bearden, Vivian Browne, Thomas Frey, Joseph Greenberg, Patrick King, Hughie Lee-Smith, Harry Overton, and Jonathan Wynberg. Writings by Gammon including personal and lecture notes as well as project drafts. Printed materials consist primarily of exhibition catalogs. Artwork includes pencil and ink sketches, advertisement mock-ups, collages, and paintings. Photographs depict Gammon at school, in the Navy, with other artists friends, and in his studio.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Reginald A. Gammon (1921-2005) was a painter and art educator, working in New York City, Michigan, and Albuquerque, New Mexico. He was a founding member of Spiral, an African American artist's collective and member of the New Mexico Afro-American Artist Guild. He also taught in the New York public schools and at Western Michigan University.

Gammon was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Reginald and Martha Brown Gammon. After graduating high school in 1941, Gammon received a scholarship to study art at the Philadelphia Museum College of Art (then called the Philadelphia Museum School of Industrial Arts). With the arrival of his draft notice, Gammon joined the Navy and served from 1944-1946 with an all-black unit stationed in Guam. After the war he returned to Philadelphia but soon moved to New York where he worked odd jobs to support his work as an artist. It was during this time in New York that he met Janice Goldberger (Jonni), whom he married in 1972.

In 1963, Gammon joined the Spiral, a group of African American artists that included Romare Bearden, Richard Mayhew, Hale Woodruff, and Alvin Hollingsworth. While a member of this group, Gammon participated in the "Black and White" exhibition at the Christopher Street Gallery. After Spiral disbanded, Gammon formed the Black Emergency Cultural Coalition with Benny Andrews. This highly political group of artists picketed the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of Modern Art to protest the exclusion of black artists and curators.

Around this same time, Gammon received a position with New York Public Schools, where he taught in the Saturday Academy Program. This program allowed children from Harlem to work with resident artists. While in this position, Gammon was recommended by Hughie Lee-Smith for a visiting lectureship at Western Michigan University. The 10-day lectureship was quickly extended into a one-semester contract. Gammon remained in this position for 21 years, finally retiring in 1991 as Full Professor Emeritus of Fine Arts and Humanities.

After leaving Michigan, Gammon settled in Albuquerque, New Mexico in 1992. Gammon became involved in civic organizations such as the New Mexico Afro-American Artist Guild and the Albuquerque United Artists. In addition to artist groups, Gammon was the artist-in-residence from 1992-2005 at the Harwood Art Center where he had a painting studio. In 1996 Gammon co-founded the New Grounds Print Workshop where he developed his final body of work, a collection of over 100 historically important prints of jazz musicians and gospel singers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 6 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1936-2006 (0.2 linear feet, Box 1)
Series 3: Writings and Notebooks, circa 1980s (0.2 linear feet, Box 2)
Series 4: Printed Material, 1955-2005 (0.4 linear feet, Box 2, OV 4)
Series 5: Photographic Material, 1927-2003 (0.2 linear feet, Box 2-3)
Series 6: Artwork, 1960s-2007 (0.5 linear feet, Box 2-3, Artifact)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Reginald Gammon papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donar have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 2007 and 2008 by Janice Gammon, Gammon's widow.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Reginald Gammon papers, 1927-2007 (bulk 1960-2005). Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid created in 2014 by intern Dominique Luster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical materials include Gammon's school records, teaching certifications, official draft notice and his certificate of honorable discharge. The series also includes a number of digital and sound recordings of interviews, home videos, and documentary recordings made about Gammon's career. Other items of interest in this series are obituaries and documents from a variety of memorial services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes 1 electronic disk (DVD): "Part 1: Reggie at DePeaux's House," "Part 2: Two Advertisements," "Part 3: Seagram's Interview"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes 1 electronic disk (DVD): "Part 1: TV interview 'Fade to Black'" "Part 2: Black & White version of 'REGGIE' followed by discussion group" "Part 3: Color version of 'REGGIE'"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with other artists, many of whom were Gammon's students, include Benny Andrews, Romare Bearden, Vivian Browne, Thomas Frey, Joseph Greenberg, Patrick King, Hughie Lee-Smith, Harry Overton, and Jonathan Wynberg. Also found are letters with various museums, galleries and arts organizations including Howard University, the LewAllen Gallery, Midtown Galleries, The Spiral Group, the Smithsonian Institution Anacostia Museum and several African American arts organizations. Topics from these letters range from personal daily life to lectures requests to exhibition solicitations. A specific file of note in this series is the correspondence concerning Gammon's only international exhibition in Rodez, France.

did.unittitle: New Mexico African American Artists Guild
New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation
Schomberg Center for Reseach in Black Culture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are lecture notes as well as a sound recording of a lecture given at Western Michigan University on "Black Artists from the Harlem Renaissance to the Present." In addition to Gammon's academic work, this series contains draft grant proposals and the first draft of a research proposal on "The Tattoo as Non-verbal Communication." Also of interest is a notebook of draft handwritten letters.

did.unittitle: Lecture, "Black Artists from the Harlem Renaissance to the Present"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The printed material primarily consists of exhibition catalogs and announcements, including the catalog "Ida y vuelta" which documents Gammon's 1998 exhibition in Rodez, France. Other materials found in this series are published illustrations and newspaper clippings that feature Gammon and his work. Two small examples of source material Gammon used for teaching and painting can also be found.

did.unittitle: Exhibition Catalog, The International Review of African American Art
Exhibition Catalog, African American Artists II
Exhibition Catalog, New York Cultural Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are photograph portraits of Gammon, and photographs depicting Gammon in school, in the Navy, and family and friends in Philadelphia. More recent photos show Gammon with other artists friends and in his painting studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Art work series is a varied and extensive sampling of Gammon's work. Mediums included in this series range from pencil sketches to fully completed and framed paintings. Some of his preliminary works show examples of Gammon's use of color and collage. The series also contains published work such as commercial posters and storyboards for children's books, as well as mock-ups for advertisements.

did.unittitle: Oversize Ink Drawings from box2, folder 48
Oversize Marker Sketches from box 2, folder 49
Oversize Pencil Sketches from box 2, folder 52
Oversize Print Mockups from box 2, folder 53-57
